The direct synthesis of isobutene from syngas is a very promising route, but there has been a bottleneck in achieving high isobutene selectivity. Here, the efficient synthesis of isobutene from syngas was achieved over a series of Zn modified m-ZrO2 catalysts. Zn species played a key role in improving the physicochemical properties of the m-ZrO2 catalyst. The structure and physicochemical properties of the catalysts were revealed by multiple characterization technique. The characterization results revealed that the introduction of Zn species significantly improved the intensity of Zr3+ and the number of oxygen vacancies. Meanwhile, it also improved the acid-base properties of the m-ZrO2 catalyst. These excellent properties were beneficial to the formation of isobutene from syngas. In CO hydrogenation, 2 % Zn/m-ZrO2 catalyst achieved 93.3 % selectivity for isobutene in C4 hydrocarbons. This enhancement of isobutene selectivity and catalytic activity is very helpful for the development of novel efficient catalysts for the direct synthesis isobutene from syngas. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO hydrogenation Zn/m-ZrO2 Isobutene Oxygen vacancy Product distribution Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction Several pathways have been developed to convert syngas (CO/H2, derived from methane, coal, or biomass) into high quality liquid fuels [1,2] and building-block chemicals such as methanol [3,4], olefins [5,6], and aromatics [7,8] via thermocatalytic hydrogenation. Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) is considered as a well-established catalytic process due to its high activity and selectivity for the target product during CO hydrogenation. Recently, progress has been made in the production of light olefins via the methanol intermediate route over bifunctional catalysts, such as, high selectivity for light olefins was obtained over bifunctional Zr-Zn/SAPO-34 [9] and In-Zr/SAPO-34 catalysts [10]. In addition, a lot of research work on bifunctional catalysts has been carried out around this route [11,12]. It is known that for the methanol synthesis by CO hydrogenation over metal oxide catalyst at low temperature is favorable because this reaction is thermodynamically favorable, while high temperature (450 ‒ 480 °C) favor the production of light olefins from methanol over zeolite [13]. The temperature mismatch between these two reactions leads to a stronger water gas shift (WGS) reaction, resulting in an elevated CO2 selectivity, because this reaction usually takes place at a higher temperature [14]. Therefore, it is very important to match the optimal reaction temperatures for both reactions. In addition, it is necessary to control the hydrogenation ability and acidity of bifunctional catalysts to obtain excellent light olefin selectivity over bifunctional catalysts, especially by modifying and reducing the acidity of zeolite catalysts to reduce the secondary reaction of primary olefins [15]. To solve the problem of temperature matching between tandem reactions and to inhibit secondary hydrogenation of primary olefins, the development of non-zeolite bifunctional catalyst may be a better choice. Zirconia has various chemical and physical properties, such as acid-base properties [16,17], redox properties and different crystalline phases [18], which is often used as a promoter in methanol synthesis or FTS. ZrO2 typically has three physical phases: tetragonal ZrO2 (t-ZrO2), monoclinic ZrO2 (m-ZrO2) and cubic ZrO2 (c-ZrO2). Among them, m-ZrO2 has excellent adsorption properties and exhibits high isobutylene selectivity in CO and CO2 hydrogenation [19–23]. The ratio of surface basic to acidic sites proved to be closely related to isosynthesis [24]. Early studies have shown that oxygen vacancies on the surface of ZrO2 can activate CO to form formic acid, which can be hydrogenated to methoxy species under H2 atmosphere [25,26]. However, the H2 dissociation ability of ZrO2 is weak and the CO conversion is low [27]. In CO hydrogenation, ZnO can promote the dissociation and adsorption of H2 and then participate in the hydrogenation reaction over Zn promoted ZrO2 catalyst [28]. Also, the addition of ZnO can introduce basic sites to promote the formation of methoxyl, which is beneficial to formic acid, dimethyl ether and finally isobutene [29]. The effect of Zn addition on the surface composition, oxygen vacancy concentration of ZrO2 and the product distribution in CO hydrogenation, especially the olefin selectivity, need to be further investigated. In this work, a series of Zn modified m-ZrO2 catalysts derived from zirconium hydroxide precursors were prepared by hydrothermal method, and their catalytic performance was evaluated for CO hydrogenation into light olefins. Various physicochemical properties, acid-base properties, and surface properties of the synthesized catalysts, including the amount of Zr3+ on the catalyst surface, were characterized to reveal the structure-performance relationship of the synthesized catalysts. The results exhibited that acid-base properties play an important role in the catalytic performance. The catalytic activity depends on the acid sites, while the ratio of base sites to acid sites affects the selectivity of isobutene. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Monoclinic ZrO2 (m-ZrO2) was prepared by hydrothermal method. Typically, zirconyl nitrate dihydrate [Zr(NO3)4∙5H2O, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd.] of 17.1 g and urea [CO(NH2)2, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd.] of 38.3 g were dissolved into deionized water of 80 mL to form solution, respectively, and then these solution was mixed together under stirring at room temperature for 0.5 h. Subsequently, the above-mentioned mixture solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave reactor for crystallization at 180 °C for 20 h. The obtained precipitate was washed with deionized water until neutral and dried at 60 °C for 12 h. Finally, the sample was calcined at 500 °C for 4 h to obtain m-ZrO2 sample. Zn modified m-ZrO2 with different Zr/Zn molar ratio was obtained by impregnation method. In brief, appropriate amount of zinc nitrate [Zn(NO3)4∙6H2O, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd.] with different Zn/Zr molar ratio (2, 1, 0.5) was dissolved into deionized water of 20 mL under stirring to form uniform solution, and then the addition of above-mentioned m-ZrO2 sample of 3.0 g under stirring for 3 h. Subsequently, the water was evaporated to dryness at 80 °C under stirring for 12 h and calcined at 500 °C for 3 h to obtain Zn modified m-ZrO2 catalyst. The catalyst was named as x%Zn/ZrO2, where x (0.5, 1, 2) represents the molar ratio of Zn to Zr. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The phase structure of the sample was obtained by the powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) on a Rigaku D/MAX-2200 PC X-ray diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.5406 Å) at 40 kV and 40 mA. The scanning speed of 8 °·min–1 in the range from 3 ° to 85 °. Raman spectra of the sample were carried out on a DXR Raman Microscopy (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA). The 532 nm line of laser was used as an excitation source. The X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were performed on a thermo scientific ESCALAB 250XI spectrometer using an Al Kα X-ray source with the pressure of the chamber of 2 × 10–9 mbar. The binding energies (BEs) were calibrated using the C1s peak of contamination carbon at 284.6 eV as a reference. Electron spin resonance (ESR) spectra were recorded at room temperature with a Bruker A300 spectrometer. All the samples were degassed before measurement. CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) was performed on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). In brief, a sample of 100 mg was pretreated with a flow of He (10 mL·min–1) at 300 °C for 0.5 h. Subsequently, the temperature was cooled down to 50 °C under a flow of He, and then CO2 was passed into the reactor for 1 h until saturated following purged by He with a flow of 10 mL·min−1 for 1 h. Finally, the temperature was increased from 50 °C to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C·min–1 in a flow of He, and the TCD signal was recorded. NH3-TPD of the synthesized samples was carried out on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 characterization system equipped with a TCD. Typically, the sample of 0.1 g was pretreated at 200 °C for 1 h, and then cooled to 50 °C. NH3 was passed into the reactor for 0.5 h and purged with He with a flow of 10 mL·min−1 for 1 h. The temperature was increased to 500 °C with a rate of 2 °C⋅min−1 and the TCD signal was recorded. The surface area and pore volume were characterized on a Quantachrom JW-BK132F type N2 adsorption analyzer. Typically, the sample of 0.5 g was degassed at 350 °C for 2 h with a flow of He before adsorption. The special surface area was calculated by Brunauer‒Emmett‒Teller (BET) equation on the basis of multi-point method. The mesopore distribution were calculated by BJH (Barrett‒Joyher‒Halenda) model. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) images were performed on a Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN TMP instrument at voltage of 300 kV. H2-TPD was conducted on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 instrument. Typically, the sample of 50 mg was pretreated in a flow of He at 500 °C for 1 h. The sample was cooled down to 50 °C under a flow of He, and then the adsorbed H2 (Ar:H2=9) for 1 h. The desorption was performed from 50 °C to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C·min−1 with a flow of He. 2.3 Catalytic activity tests CO hydrogenation reaction was performed in a fixed-bed stainless steel reactor (8 mm inner diameter). Typically, the catalyst of 1 mL was loaded into the reactor and pretreated at 450 °C with a N2 flow of 30 mL·min−1 for 2 h, and then the temperature of catalyst was cooled to reaction temperature of 400 °C. Subsequently, the pressure was increased to 2 MPa and the syngas (H2/CO = 2) was fed into the reactor with a GHSV of 500 h − 1. The effluent gas was analyzed online with a gas chromatograph (GC-9160) equipped with TCD and flame ionization detector (FID), which was equipped a TDX-01 column (2 m × 3 mm) for C1 products analysis and Al2O3 capillary column (50 m × 0.53 mm × 40 μm) for C1–C5 hydrocarbons products, respectively. The CO conversion and products selectivity are defined as follows: (1) XCO (%) = (Fin × Yin,CO – Fout × Yout,CO) / (Fin × Yin,CO) × 100% (2) Si = Fout · Yi,out / (Fin · Yin,CO · XCO) × 100% where, XCO ‒ the conversion of CO, Fin ‒ the molar flow of inlet gas, Fout ‒ the molar flow of outlet gas, Yin,CO ‒ the CO fraction in feedstock, Yout,CO ‒ the CO fraction in tail gas, Si ‒ the selectivity of hydrocarbon with carbon number i at the outlet, Yi,out ‒ the hydrocarbon with carbon number i at the outlet. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural and morphology characterization XRD and Raman were used to reveal the structure of the catalysts, and the results are shown in Fig. 1 and Fig. 2 , respectively. As shown in Fig. 1, the characteristic diffraction peaks of m-ZrO2 appear at 2θ = 17.4°, 24.2°, 28.2°, 31.5°, 34.4° and 50.2° for all catalysts, corresponding to the (100), (011), (−111), (111), (002) and (220) crystal planes of m-ZrO2, respectively [30–32]. For the Zn modified m-ZrO2 catalysts, the diffraction peak intensity increases compared to the m-ZrO2 catalyst. However, the characteristic diffraction peaks of Zn species were not detected on the Zn modified m-ZrO2 catalyst, indicating that the lower loading of Zn species was highly dispersed on the m-ZrO2 surface or the particle size of Zn species was smaller than the detection limit of XRD. Fig. 2 shows the Raman spectra of the m-ZrO2 and Zn modified m-ZrO2 catalysts. All catalysts exhibited characteristic peaks at 230 cm−1, 339 cm−1, 351 cm−1, 366 cm−1, 484 cm−1, 621 cm−1, and 639 cm−1, which were assigned to the m-ZrO2 phase [33]. Meanwhile, no characteristic peaks of Zn species were observed in the Zn modified m-ZrO2 catalysts, which together with the XRD results revealed that Zn species were highly dispersed on the m-ZrO2 catalyst surface. TEM was used to reveal the microstructure of the catalysts, and the results are shown in Fig. 3 . m-ZrO2 and Zn modified m-ZrO2 catalysts both consist of irregular nanoparticles with a particle size of about 20–25 nm. m-ZrO2 and Zn modified m-ZrO2 catalysts exhibited a distinct lattice in HRTEM images with sizes of 0.319 nm, 0.316 nm, 0.311 nm, and 0.310 nm, which were attributed to the (−111) crystal plane of m-ZrO2 (Fig. 3e, f). This result indicated that the introduction of Zn species affects the structure of m-ZrO2. ZrO2 lattice was detected in the 0.5 % Zn/m-ZrO2 catalyst (Fig. 3f), and no ZnO lattice was observed, suggesting that when Zn species were dispersed as Zn2+ or ZnO in m-ZrO2 internally [34]. However, with increasing Zn content, ZnO(100) lattice plane was observed in 1 % Zn/m-ZrO2 catalyst with a lattice spacing of 0.279 nm (Fig. 3g) and 0.280 nm for the 2 % Zn/m-ZrO2 catalyst (Fig. 3h). 3.2 Textural properties As shown in Table 1 , the addition of Zn increased the specific surface area, pore volume and pore diameter of the catalysts. The specific surface area of m-ZrO2 is much lower than t-ZrO2 [35].The pore volume and pore diameter exhibited a linear relationship with the addition of Zn, which favored the activation of CO. The pore size distribution is shown in Fig. 4 . The pore diameter of Zn modified m-ZrO2 catalyst increased with increasing Zn/Zr molar ratio, and its maximum pore size was about 15 nm. 3.3 Acid-base properties The acidity and basicity of m-ZrO2 catalyst is very important to its catalytic performance. The acidic sites of m-ZrO2 can promote CO activation [36], while the basic sites can improve the selectivity of isobutene during CO hydrogenation [37,38]. NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD were used to detect the acidity and basicity of m-ZrO2 and Zn modified m-ZrO2 catalysts. As shown in Fig. 5 , the adsorption peaks of NH3 at about 100 °C and 400 °C corresponded to the weak acid sites and medium strong acid sites of m-ZrO2, respectively. With the increase of Zn content, the acidity of Zn modified m-ZrO2 catalysts increases (Table 1), which is beneficial to CO activation and the increase of activity. Two CO2 desorption peaks were detected for all catalysts, which were attributed to the desorption of adsorbed CO2 on the weak and strong base sites of m-ZrO2, respectively. As shown in Fig. 6 , the desorption peaks below 250 °C belong to the weak adsorption sites of CO2, while the adsorption peaks at 350–550 °C are the strong base sites of the catalysts. both m-ZrO2 and Zn modified m-ZrO2 catalysts exhibited weak base sites. the CO2 desorption peaks of m-ZrO2 are evident at around 500 °C. As shown in Table 1, the surface base/acid ratio of m-ZrO2 decreased after the introduction of Zn species. However, the surface base/acid ratio of Zn modified m-ZrO2 catalysts increased with the increase of Zn content, which was favorable for the formation of olefin products, especially isobutene. A low temperature adsorption peak was observed at 180 ℃ for the catalyst, and at 220 to 230 ℃ for the Zn supported m-ZrO2 catalyst. At 390 ℃, the Zn/m-ZrO2 catalysts has a high temperature adsorption peak with a surface of about 400 ℃, the adsorption of CO on Zn/m-ZrO2 catalyst was increased. In addition, as the temperature increases, the ability of m-ZrO2 catalyst to adsorb CO increases rapidly, which may be related to the long-standing time of the catalyst (Fig. S1). H2-TPD was used to reveal the adsorption characteristics of the catalyst on H2, and the results are shown in Fig. 7 . Two distinct desorption peaks were observed in the range of 60–200 °C and 350–550 °C for all samples. The order of low-temperature desorption peak areas of the m-ZrO2 and Zn modified m-ZrO2 catalyst decreased from 0. 95 → 0. 74 → 0. 56 → 0. 83 with increasing Zn content. The high-temperature desorption peak areas gradually increased with increasing Zn content. The adsorption of H2 for 0.5 % Zn/ZrO, 1% Zn/ZrO2 and 2% Zn/ZrO2 catalysts were 1.39, 1.52 and 2.05 times higher than that of ZrO2 catalysts, respectively. These results suggest that the introduction of Zn species can increase the adsorption capacity of H2 and promote the dissociation of H2. 3.4 Oxygen vacancies and Zr species analysis To reveal the surface oxygen vacancies and chemical states of the reference m-ZrO2 catalyst and Zn modified m-ZrO2 catalysts, we performed XPS characterization technique. As shown in Fig. 8 (A, B), the O 1 s energy level spectra at 529.7 eV, 531.2 eV and 532.1 eV were attributed to lattice oxygen (OL), oxygen vacancies (OV) and chemisorbed oxygen (OC) [39–41], respectively. The full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the fitted peak in XPS spectra and the peak position are shown in Table S1. From Table 2 , the surface oxygen content of spent catalysts increased slightly compared to fresh catalysts. Furthermore, as the Zn content of all fresh and used Zn modified m-ZrO2 catalysts increased, the OV/(OL+OV) ratio (oxygen vacancy concentration) first increased to a maximum value of 15.5% and 16.3% for 1% Zn/m-ZrO2 and then decreased. Based on the binding energy of Zr 3d5/2, the peaks at 181.9 eV and 184.4 eV were attributed to 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 of the reduced Zr species, which was associated with oxygen vacancies [42,43] (Fig. 8C). Electron spin resonance (ESR) was used to detect unpaired electrons in catalyst to identify oxygen vacancies in zirconium dioxide. The g-factor in ESR was related to the internal motion and magnetic moment of the radical. Different g-factors represent different radicals and oxygen vacancies. As shown in Fig. 9 , the ESR spectra of m-ZrO2 and Zn modified m-ZrO2 catalysts were similar, with a strong spin resonance peak appeared at g = 2.005, indicating the presence of unsaturated Zr3+ and the intensity of Zr3+ correlates with oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface [44–46]. With the increase of Zn content, the strength of Zr3+ and the number of oxygen vacancies gradually increased. For CO hydrogenation, CO can be activated on the oxygen vacancy of m-ZrO2 [47]. The addition of Zn increased the oxygen vacancy, which was beneficial to CO conversion and improved activity of the catalysts. 3.5 Catalytic performance We evaluated the catalytic performance of different ZrO2 species with respect to CO hydrogenation (Fig. S2). m-ZrO2 exhibited excellent adsorption properties and high isobutylene selectivity. The optimized optimal reaction conditions were carried out to test the catalytic performance of Zn/m-ZrO2 catalysts for CO hydrogenation (Fig. S3). The catalytic activity and product distribution (TOS=48 h) of m-ZrO2 and Zn modified m-ZrO2 catalysts for CO hydrogenation were listed in Table 3 . m-ZrO2 catalysts showed an increased catalytic activity compared to m-ZrO2 catalysts. A positive correlation between catalytic activity and oxygen vacancy concentration can be found. Increasing oxygen vacancies is beneficial for the activation of CO and improves the catalytic activity. The selectivity of CO2 and CH4 decreased with the increase of Zn content, while the selectivity of C5+ hydrocarbons increased, which was mainly due to the increased H2 adsorption capacity after the introduction of Zn. The formation of more dissociated hydrogen on the Zr-Zn oxide surface promoted the hydrogenation reaction and the formation of more heavy hydrocarbon products, which decreased the CO2 production. However, the enhanced H2 adsorption did not promote further hydrogenation of olefins. The selectivity of light olefins slightly increased. 1% Zn/m-ZrO2 catalyst exhibited the highest selectivity for light olefins. 2% Zn/m-ZrO2 catalyst displayed the highest catalytic activity and isobutene selectivity. These results indicated that the selectivity of light olefins could be improved by the addition of moderate amounts of Zn species, while the addition of excess Zn species was beneficial to the CO conversion and the formation of isobutene in the C4 fraction. Among them, 2% Zn/m-ZrO2 catalyst could reach up to 93.3 % of isobutene in C4 olefins in CO hydrogenation reaction and the catalyst exhibited good stability as shown in Fig. 10 . 4 Conclusion Zn modified m-ZrO2 catalysts prepared by wet impregnation exhibited excellent isobutene selectivity for the direct synthesis of isobutene from syngas. 2% Zn/m-ZrO2 catalyst exhibited a superior isobutene selectivity of 93.3% in C4 hydrocarbons. The introduction of Zn species into m-ZrO2 catalysts improved the formation of isobutene and CO conversion and suppressed the by-products CO2 production. Characterizations showed that Zn species could improve the number of oxygen vacancies and acid-base properties of m-ZrO2 catalysts, which should be responsible for these positive changes. This work presents an efficient 2% Zn/m-ZrO2 catalyst for direct synthesis of isobutene from syngas and provides insight into of the roles of Zn species in promoting the physicochemical properties and catalytic performance of m-ZrO2 catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The direct synthesis of isobutene from syngas is a very promising route, but there has been a bottleneck in achieving high isobutene selectivity. Here, the efficient synthesis of isobutene from syngas was achieved over a series of Zn modified m-ZrO2 catalysts. Zn species played a key role in improving the physicochemical properties of the m-ZrO2 catalyst. The structure and physicochemical properties of the catalysts were revealed by multiple characterization technique. The characterization results revealed that the introduction of Zn species significantly improved the intensity of Zr3+ and the number of oxygen vacancies. Meanwhile, it also improved the acid-base properties of the m-ZrO2 catalyst. These excellent properties were beneficial to the formation of isobutene from syngas. In CO hydrogenation, 2 % Zn/m-ZrO2 catalyst achieved 93.3 % selectivity for isobutene in C4 hydrocarbons. This enhancement of isobutene selectivity and catalytic activity is very helpful for the development of novel efficient catalysts for the direct synthesis isobutene from syngas.
coredata.dc:title: Highly selective formation of isobutene over Zn modified m-ZrO2 catalyst from syngas
